Department of Applied Chemistry Graduate School of Engineering Tohoku University 6-6-07 Aoba Aramaki Aoba-ku Sendai Miyagi 980-8579 Japan Graphical abstract Hydrodenitrogenation (HDN) of 1-cyclohexylethylamine to ethylcyclohexane was investigated with various Ru-based catalysts. Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 (1 wt% Ru, 4 wt% Ir) catalyst was found to be superior to other supported Ru catalysts in terms of activity and selectivity to ethylcyclohexane. Characterization with XRD, TEM-EDX and XAFS showed that uniform Ru-Ir alloy particles of approximately 4 nm in size were formed on α-Al2O3. The optimal Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 catalyst gave 94 % yield of ethylcyclohexane. The time-course results and the reaction results of bis-(1-cyclohexylethyl)-amine (coupled compound of the substrate) demonstrated that the direct CN cleavage route and indirect route via the coupled compound both proceeded in the HDN of 1-cyclohexylethylamine. The propylamine-TPD results with H2 treatment after the adsorption of propylamine on the catalyst suggested that the adsorption of H2 and amine was favorable on the Ru and Ir species, respectively. The catalyst was reusable after washing with ethanol with a slight loss of activity. The catalyst was also effective for the HDN reaction of other amines, and the HDN of some substrates proceeded mainly in the indirect route via the coupled compound. Keywords Hydrodenitrogenation Ruthenium Iridium Heterogeneous catalyst Alloy Hydrogenolysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Reactions to remove heteroatoms (S, N, O) from organic compounds are important in fuel refining [1,2]. Petroleum resources contain a lot of sulfur and nitrogen, and its combustion releases SOx and NOx, both of which cause severe environmental issues such as acid rain. Synthetic crudes, such as those derived from coal and biomass, contain a lot of oxygen. Too high oxygen content in fuels decreases their heating value. These factors require the removal of heteroatoms from fuels. The hydrodesulfurization (HDS) process using sulfide catalysts such as NiMoS and CoMoS has been studied and can remove nitrogen and oxygen under the same conditions as well as sulfur [2–8]. However, these sulfide catalysts require the feed containing toxic H2S, which is unfavorable for the systems that only remove nitrogen (hydrodenitrogenation, HDN) or oxygen (hydrodeoxygenation, HDO). In recent years, HDO reactions using metal and/or metal oxide catalysts have been extensively studied with the increasing emphasis on the utilization of oxygen-rich biomass resources [9–15]. Raw biomass and many biomass-derived compounds contain various types of oxygenated functional groups. Catalysts for partial HDO with various selectivities as well as those for total HDO have been developed thus far, and their activity and selectivity are well-known to depend significantly on the combination of components (metal, additive metal or metal oxide, and support) [16–22]. Compared to HDO, studies on HDN are limited. However, HDN research has a great potential as a means of effectively utilizing amino acids, which are renewable feedstock. Due to their diverse skeletal structures, amino acids would be converted into various molecules with structure that is difficult to be constructed from other biomass sources [23]. As described above, research on HDN has traditionally been conducted using sulfide catalysts that were originally developed for HDS. The following three reaction pathways have been proposed for metal-sulfide-catalyzed reactions [6,7,24]. (1) Direct elimination of NH3 from substrate upon the removal of a hydrogen atom at the β-C atom relative to the amino group, followed by olefin saturation. (2) Nucleophilic substitution of the NH2 group by H2S then SH group decomposition (most dominant in sulfide-catalyzed reactions). (3) Direct hydrogenolysis of the CN bond. Among them, the pathway (3) can proceed over metal surfaces. The CN bond cleavage reaction of methylamine over noble metals such as Ru and Rh has been reported, for which the pathway (3) has been invoked [25,26]. Other than sulfide-type catalysts, HDN using noble metal catalysts for more complicated substrates has been reported [27–32]. Most of them have used heterocyclic aromatic compounds consisting of pyridine and pyrrole as substrates. These systems were operated at very high temperatures (typically 573 K or more) and accompany breaking down the carbon framework of substrate; for example, the HDN reaction of pyridine gave propane and butane as the main products [30]. Currently, there are a few examples of CN bond cleavage reactions for the effective utilization of amino acids. De Vos et al. produced glutaric acid via CN bond cleavage of N,N-dimethylglutamic acid using Pt/TiO2 catalyst [33]. Zhang et al. produced ε-caprolactam via the CN bond cleavage of α-dimethylamino-ε-caprolactam using Ir/H-Beta catalyst [34]. However, these systems used dimethylamino group as a leaving group, and the atom efficiency is lower than the case of HDN removing amino group as NH3. There are a few catalysts reported for CN bond cleavage reactions of alkylamines, but many of them are sulfide-based ones. Table S1 summarizes the reported non-sulfide catalysts for HDN of alkylamines [36,37] as well as typical sulfide catalysts [6,7,35]. All the systems used high temperature (≥513 K), and many systems were operated in low concentration of substrate. In this work, we chose 1-cyclohexylethylamine (denoted as 1-CEA), which has an amino group (NH2) at a sterically hindered secondary position, as a model substrate as shown in Eq. (1). Target HDN product is ethylcyclohexane without change of carbon framework of 1-CEA, and direct metal-catalyzed CN hydrogenolysis is a preferable reaction route because this route does not involve reactive intermediates that cause undesirable side reactions. Hibbitts et al. used DFT calculations to examine the hydrogenolysis of CX (X = C, N, O, S, Cl) bonds and revealed that Ru exhibits high activity for cleaving all CX bonds by direct hydrogenolysis [38]. In fact, Ru has been reported to show high activity in wide range of hydrogenolysis reactions for CC [39–44], CO [15,45–58], and CCl [59–61] bonds. Therefore, we focused on Ru-based catalysts and determined the optimal one by selections of support, second metal, and the composition. We also explored the applicability of the developed catalyst (Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 (1 wt% Ru, 4 wt% Ir)) to other alkylamines and discussed the mechanism of the direct CN bond cleavage on the bimetallic catalyst including the roles of each supported metal. (1) 2 Experimental Suppliers and purity of all reagents are listed in Table S2. 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Ru/support (Ru = 5 wt%) (support = activated carbon, SiO2, ZrO2, CeO2, Rutile TiO2, P25 TiO2, α-Al2O3, γ-Al2O3; suppliers and properties are listed in Table S3, all supports were in powdery form) catalysts were prepared by the impregnation method using Ru(NO)(NO3)x(OH)y (x + y = 3) as the Ru precursor. The sample was dried at 383 K overnight. The Ru-M/α-Al2O3 (M = Ir, Pd, Mo, Co. Re, Pt, Ag) catalysts were prepared by the sequential impregnation method. First, α-Al2O3 prepared by calcination of γ-Al2O3 (Sumitomo Chemical KHO-24) at 1423 K in air for 3 h (BET surface area 10 m2 g−1) [62,63] was impregnated with Ru(NO)(NO3)x(OH)y (x + y = 3). After drying at 383 K overnight, Ir (typical M) was loaded using H2IrCl6 as the precursor. The resulting sample was then dried at 383 K for 12 h. The dried sample was reduced in a quartz tube under a H2 flow (30 mL min−1) at 573 K for 1h and then passivated with 2 % O2/He (30 mL min−1) at room temperature. 2.2 Activity test and product analysis The activity tests were carried out in a stainless-steel autoclave (inner volume 190 mL) equipped with a glass inner vessel. Substrate, solvent, and the reduced catalyst were charged into the autoclave together with a stirring bar. After replacing the air in the autoclave five times with H2, 1 MPa H2 (at r.t.) was added, and the reactor was heated. The reaction started when the temperature reached 2 K below the target temperature, and the target temperature was maintained throughout the reaction. The reaction mixture was magnetically stirred at 250 rpm. The reaction results were hardly changed by the change of stirring rate (150–350 rpm), indicating that the reaction was not controlled by the diffusion of reactants (Table S4). After an appropriate reaction time, the reactor was cooled by being immersed in a cold-water bath. The quantitation of products in the liquid phase was carried out with a GC (Shimadzu GC-2014) equipped with a CP-Sil 5 column (diameter 0.25 mm, 50 m) and FID. The commercially unavailable compounds were identified by using GC-mass spectrometry (GC–MS; Shimadzu, GCMS-QP2010 Ultra, equipped with the same column as GC-FID, electron ionization (EI) and chemical ionization (CI) modes). The GC–MS data are shown in Figs. S7-S13. The conversion, selectivity, and carbon balance were calculated with the following equations (Eqs. (2)–(5)): (2) Conversion % = mole of substrate consumed mole of input substrate × 100 (3) Yield % = C‐based mole of product C‐based mole of input substrate × 100 (4) Selectivity % = C‐based mole of product sum of C‐based mole of products × 100 (5) Carbon balance % = sum of C‐based mole of products + C‐based mole of residual substrate C‐based mole of input substrate × 100 In some runs, the carbon balance slightly exceeded 100 % mainly because of the analysis error of remaining substrate, especially when the conversion was low. In these cases, the sum of product yields is closer to the real conversion, and therefore the sum of product yields was used as “conversion” instead of Eq. (2). Reuse tests of catalysts were conducted as follows. The reaction was carried out in multiple autoclaves under the identical conditions to each other. The spent catalysts were collected from each autoclave by filtration and mixed together. The mixed sample was washed three times with ethanol (10 mL) and dried at room temperature. For reuse tests with a regeneration process, the catalyst was calcined at 773 K for 3 h before the 1st use (fresh), followed by hydrogen reduction at 573 K for 1 h. The spent catalysts were washed three times with ethanol (10 mL), followed by drying at 383 K for 20 min, then calcined at 573 K for 1 h and reduced with H2 at 573 K for 1 h. In both cases (with or without regeneration), the total loss of catalyst during the recovery and regeneration processes was less than the amount required for one batch, and the next cycle of reaction was carried out with less autoclaves by one under the same conditions. 2.3 Catalyst characterization N2 physisorption measurement was conducted at 77 K to examine the specific surface area of the catalyst using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation with an automated instrument (Gemini VII 2360, Micromeritics). The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of catalysts were collected using a Rigaku MiniFlex600 diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation) under air. Scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) images were taken with a HITACHI HD-2700 microscope. For STEM measurement, the catalyst was dispersed in ethanol and dropped on a Cu microgrid under air. A catalyst analyzer BELCAT Ⅱ (MicrotracMRB; equipped with a thermal conductivity detector) was adopted for CO chemisorption measurement. Prior to each run, the catalyst was reduced under a H2 flow (50 mL min−1) at 573 K for 1 h. Afterward, CO pulses were introduced to the catalyst bed at 323 K until the saturation of catalyst surfaces by CO. Dispersion was calculated as the ratio of adsorbed CO amount to total metal amount. The X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) measurement was conducted at the BL14B2 station of SPring-8 (Proposal No. 2025A1634). The fluorescence mode was used to record the data of Ir L 3-edge spectra for the catalyst samples with 1 wt% Ir, while all the other data of Ru K-edge and Ir L 3-edge spectra were obtained with the transmission mode. The samples were handled in a N2 atmosphere and were not exposed to air before and during the measurement. The empirical phase shift and amplitude function of RuRu and IrIr bonds were extracted from the data of Ru powder and Ir foil, respectively. The FEFF 8.20 program was used to calculate the theoretical curves of RuIr and IrRu. The data processing and curve fitting were carried out with REX2000 Ver. 2.6 program. Temperature-programmed desorption of propylamine was conducted with an automated apparatus BELCAT II (MicrotracMRB) equipped with a quadrupole mass spectrometer (Q-MS; BELMASS, MicrotracMRB). In each run, 0.30 g of the sample was pretreated in H2 (50 mL min−1) at 573 K for 1 h, exposed to propylamine steam (which was generated by bubbling Ar to propylamine) at 323 K for 30 min, and further treated in Ar (50 mL min−1) at 323 K for 30 min. Afterward, the desorption profile of probe molecules was monitored with Q-MS in the temperature range from 323 K to 1273 K with a 10 K min−1 ramp rate in an Ar flow (30 mL min−1). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst development 3.1.1 Support effect As summarized in Fig. 1 (detailed data: Table S5), the screening of supports for monometallic Ru catalysts was initially conducted for the selective hydrodenitrogenation (HDN) of 1-cyclohexylethylamine (1-CEA) at 453 K. For the fair and precise comparison of product selectivity among the catalysts, the reactions were carried out at about 30 % level of conversion by intentionally adjusting the reaction time and catalyst amount. Products frequently observed over many catalysts were ethylcyclohexane (target product), methylcyclohexane (CC hydrogenolysis product of ethylcyclohexane), bis-(1-cyclohexylethyl)-amine (coupled compound of substrate), 1-cyclohexylethanol, and cyclohexanemethylamine (CC hydrogenolysis product of substrate). 1-Cyclohexylethanol is the hydrolysis product, and its formation thus requires water; we suppose that the water adsorbed on the catalyst and/or contaminated in a reactor was involved in the formation of 1-cyclohexylethanol. Methylcyclohexane was produced possibly from ethylcyclohexane and cyclohexanemethylamine because both intermediates were detected when the selectivity of methylcyclohexane was high. The possible reaction pathway of these products is shown in Scheme 1 . Ru/α-Al2O3, Ru/Rutile TiO2, and Ru/CeO2 catalysts produced ethylcyclohexane as a major product. Among them, Ru/α-Al2O3 catalyst showed the simplest selectivity pattern; only the major byproducts were methylcyclohexane and cyclohexanemethylamine, the CC hydrogenolysis products. Over Ru/Rutile TiO2 and Ru/CeO2, three byproducts (i.e., methylcyclohexane, coupled compound, and 1-cyclohexylethanol) were obtained in similar selectivities. Ru/AC and Ru/SiO2 showed higher activity in terms of 1-CEA conversion (short reaction time and/or lower catalyst amount to obtain ∼30 % conversion), but the main product was bis-(1-cyclohexylethyl)-amine, resulting in the low selectivity to ethylcyclohexane. Also, γ-Al2O3 gave high selectivity of bis-(1-cyclohexylethyl)-amine (coupled compound). Generally, AC and SiO2 with larger surface area (Table S3) lead to the formation of well-dispersed Ru particles. It can be suggested that the high surface Ru content leads to the high activity for 1-CEA conversion. Also, highly dispersed Ru particles were reported to promote amine coupling [64,65], which is an undesired reaction in this study. In addition, there are some reports that supports with Lewis acidity promote amine coupling because Lewis acid catalyzes the formation of imine which is an intermediate of the coupling reaction [66–68]. Therefore, AC, SiO2, and γ-Al2O3 which have high surface area and/or Lewis acidity produced the coupled compound with high selectivity. On the other hand, α-Al2O3 is known as an inert support with few surface functional groups [69] and has low surface area (10 m2/g for our one), leading to the high selectivity to hydrogenolysis products. We, therefore, selected α-Al2O3 as the appropriate support in the following study, and further modification was applied to Ru/α-Al2O3 to suppress the formation of methylcyclohexane. 3.1.2 Addition of second metal to Ru/α-Al2O3 Another metal was added to Ru/α-Al2O3 to improve the catalytic performance. We chose Mo [70–73], Co [56,74,75], and Re [58,76–78], all of which are often used as additive metals to supported Ru catalysts for hydrogenolysis reactions. Also, we chose Ir, Pd, Pt, and Ag because there are many studies that alloys between noble metals enhance catalytic performance [16,79–81]. Fig. 2 A (detailed data: Table S6) shows the reaction results over the various Ru-M/α-Al2O3 at the M/Ru molar ratio of 1/8. The addition of Ir increased activity and yield of ethylcyclohexane. Ir has been reported as an active component of catalysts for ammonia decomposition [82–84]; the role of Ir is discussed in more detail in the mechanism section. The other Ru-M/α-Al2O3 catalysts showed activity and ethylcyclohexane selectivity similar to or lower than Ru/α-Al2O3. In the cases of non-noble metals as M (Mo, Co and Re), the small effects can be due to the absence of direct contact between Ru and M; located at different sites on support and/or dissolved into the reaction media. The composition of Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 was next optimized. Considering that both Ru and Ir are expensive noble metals, the total loading amount of Ru and Ir was fixed at 5 wt%. As shown in Fig. 2B (detailed data: Table S7), the Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 catalyst with 1 wt% Ru and 4 wt% Ir exhibited the excellent activity and selectivity of ethylcyclohexane. The formation of CC dissociation product, methylcyclohexane, was suppressed by the Ir addition. Monometallic Ir/α-Al2O3 also showed some activity in the HDN of 1-CEA; however, its activity was much lower than that of Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 (1 wt% Ru, 4 wt% Ir). The comparison in chemical view is rather complex because of the differences in the total number of metal atoms and in the particle size (dispersion) among catalysts. Therefore, TOF was calculated from the number of surface metal atoms of each catalyst (details will be discussed later) and the reaction results at low conversion level (Table S8). The highest TOF was obtained with (2 wt% Ru, 3 wt% Ir) catalyst (66 h−1) and that of (1 wt% Ru, 4 wt% Ir) catalyst was comparable (60 h−1). The latter catalyst had higher dispersion, leading to its higher activity. The reaction rate is faster with Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 (1 wt% Ru, 4 wt% Ir) than with the physical mixture of 1 wt% Ru/α-Al2O3 and 4 wt% Ir/α-Al2O3 (Table S9). These results indicate that the bimetallic structure is highly effective in this HDN reaction. In the following study, “Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3” stands for the optimum composition catalyst at Ru 1 wt% and Ir 4 wt% unless otherwise noted. 3.2 Effect of reaction conditions 3.2.1 Reaction solvent The effect of solvent was investigated in the HDN of 1-CEA over Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3, and the results are shown in Table S10. Alkane solvents and no-solvent system gave good yields of ethylcyclohexane, and decane provided the lowest yields of 1-cyclohexylethanol and the coupled compound. The no-solvent system had difficulty in the handling of the reaction solution because of the too low amount of liquid phase, decreasing the carbon balance. All the oxygen-containing solvents showed much lower yield of ethylcyclohexane. Water solvent gave the high conversion of 1-CEA, but the main product was 1-cyclohexylethanol due to the hydrolysis of 1-CEA. Ether solvents (1,4-dioxane, 1,2-dimethoxyethane, and diisopropyl ether) gave the coupled compound as the main product. We used decane as the standard solvent in this study. Considering the inert nature of alkane (decane) solvent, the functionality of solvent is disadvantageous to the HDN of 1-CEA by the competitive adsorption between 1-CEA and solvent molecules. 3.2.2 Hydrogen pressure Fig. 3 (detailed data: Table S11) shows the results of the reaction at different hydrogen pressure (0.1–5 MPa). The effect of hydrogen pressure on the conversion and ethylcyclohexane yield was rather complicated, while the selectivity was not largely changed. At both the short reaction time (4 h) and long reaction time (16 h), the ethylcyclohexane yield was slightly decreased with the increase of hydrogen pressure up to 1 MPa. The further increase of hydrogen pressure much decreased the ethylcyclohexane yield, in an inversely proportional manner. In this context, the activity of Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 catalyst increased at lower hydrogen pressure. The appropriate hydrogen pressure for this reaction was determined to be in the range of 0.1–1 MPa. From the perspective of the ease of reaction operation, we chose 1 MPa of H2 as the standard pressure. The effect of hydrogen pressure on the catalysis is strongly related to the reaction mechanism of hydrogenolysis reactions, and we will discuss the relationship in the mechanism section. 3.3 Performance of Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 catalyst 3.3.1 Time course of HDN of 1-CEA over Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 Fig. 4A (detailed data: Table S12) shows the time course of HDN of 1-CEA over the Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 catalyst at 453 K. The conversion and ethylcyclohexane yield increased linearly, and 97 % conversion and 91 % ethylcyclohexane yield were achieved at 24 h. The linear increase of yield suggests the strong adsorption of 1-CEA (zero-order dependence with respect to 1-CEA concentration) and negligible deactivation under the conditions. This behavior can also rule out the inhibition of reaction by the products, i.e., competitive adsorption of products (ethylcyclohexane and ammonia) with 1-CEA substrate. The reaction at 24 h or longer did not change the selectivity, indicating that overhydrogenolysis of ethylcyclohexane to methylcyclohexane did not occur. The presence of ammonia was confirmed through the analysis of the gas phase after the reaction (Fig. S1). At the shorter reaction time, the coupled compound was observed in low selectivity (<15 %) while disappeared at 24 h. This behavior suggests the involvement of the coupled compound in the formation of ethylcyclohexane. To confirm the zero-order dependence with respect to the 1-CEA concentration, the reaction was conducted with different amounts of solvent (Table S13). The results showed that the activity decrease by the increase of solvent amount was marginal, confirming the very low reaction order with respect to 1-CEA concentration. Fig. 4 B and 4C (detailed data in Table S12) show the time course of the HDN of 1-CEA over Ir/α-Al2O3 and Ru/α-Al2O3, respectively, at 453 K. Over Ir/α-Al2O3, the reaction was slower than that over Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3, and the selectivity to the coupled compound was higher in the whole conversion range. Over Ru/α-Al2O3, the reaction was slower than those over Ir/α-Al2O3 and Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3, and the yield of methylcyclohexane was significant, decreasing the yield of ethylcyclohexane. 3.3.2 HDN pathways over Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 In order to examine whether the coupled compound, bis-(1-cyclohexylethyl)-amine, is an intermediate of the main pathway of ethylcyclohexane formation, the reactions of the coupled compound as a substrate were conducted. As shown in Table 1 , for all the catalysts (Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3, Ru/α-Al2O3, and Ir/α-Al2O3), the HDN rate of the coupled compound was slightly higher than that of 1-CEA. The HDN rate of the coupled compound represented by the total yield of ethylcyclohexane and 1-CEA was in the order of Ir/α-Al2O3 > Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 > Ru/α-Al2O3, suggesting that Ir is effective for the HDN via the coupled compound. Meanwhile, in the reaction of 1-CEA at the similar conversion (around 50 %), the selectivity to the coupled compound over Ru/α-Al2O3 (2.9 % in 24 h, detailed data: Table S12) and Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 (11 % in 8 h, detailed data: Table S12) was lower than that over Ir/α-Al2O3 (23 % in 24 h, detailed data: Table S12). Therefore, although the HDN pathway via the coupled compound is involved, the dominant pathway is the direct CN bond cleavage of 1-CEA in the HDN reaction of 1-CEA especially over Ru/α-Al2O3 and Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 catalysts. Another important point is that the selectivity to 1-CEA in the HDN of the coupled compound was low over all the catalysts, although the primary CN hydrogenolysis products of the coupled compound were 1-CEA and ethylcyclohexane. This means that the two CN bonds in the coupled compound were mainly dissociated simultaneously, or the second CN dissociation occurred quickly before the desorption to release 1-CEA to the liquid phase. 3.3.3 Reusability of the Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 The reusability of the Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 catalyst was evaluated in the HDN of 1-CEA (Fig. 5 , detailed data: Table S14). The activity of the Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 catalyst slightly decreased upon its multiple uses when the recovered catalyst was simply reused after filtration, washing with ethanol, and drying. The possible causes of decreased activity are the coverage of metal surface with organic deposits and the aggregation of metal particles. The cause of activity decrease will be discussed later based on characterization results. When the spent catalyst was calcined before its reuse to remove the organic deposits, the activity was more severely decreased, probably by aggregation of metal species (Fig. S2, detailed data: Table S14). Catalysts which have higher stability and can be regenerated are necessary to be developed in practical view. 3.3.4 Substrate scope of Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 The Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 catalyst was applied to the HDN of various amines (Table 2 ). The details of product identification by GC–MS are shown in Figs. S7–S13. For all the tested primary amines, the main product at short reaction time was the coupled compound (secondary amine). The HDN of the coupled compound proceeded at longer reaction time, and the corresponding alkane was obtained in good yield from acyclic substrates. The formation of hydrocarbon from cyclohexylamine and cyclohexanemethylamine was quite slow. In the HDN reaction of primary amines, the apparent rates of formation of the complete HDN product, alkanes, were in the following order: The results of HDN of primary amines (R-NH2) can be summarized as follows: primary R and non-bulky secondary R give high selectivity to the coupled compound at low conversion, but bulky primary R gives low rate of the second step, the HDN of the coupled compound. Non-bulky R gives high HDN rate of the coupled compound to produce alkane in good yield. In the case of bulky secondary R (1-CEA), the formation of the coupled compound is suppressed and direct HDN proceeded to produce alkane in good yield. In the HDN reaction of secondary amines, the HDN rate of bis-(1-cyclohexylethyl)amine was higher than that of dihexylamine. These results suggest that the CN bond cleavage of secondary amines more easily occurs for substrates with secondary alkyl groups. 3.4 Catalyst characterization The support of the optimized catalyst (α-Al2O3) is an inert one in view of both redox and acid/base property. Furthermore, the reaction solvent was inert alkane which does not interact with support. Therefore, we focused on the structure of supported metal species, and structure-performance relationship is discussed here for the series of monometallic or bimetallic Ir-Ru catalysts with different ratio on α-Al2O3 support. XRD was initially conducted to investigate the crystal structure of metal particles in the spent catalysts with the different molar ratios of Ru and Ir (Fig. 6 A). Since the diffraction peaks of Ru and α-Al2O3 overlapped with each other, the peaks assignable to α-Al2O3 were subtracted from the pattern of each catalyst (Fig. 6B). The peaks attributable to the hcp structure of Ru were observed for Ru/α-Al2O3, and a peak from the fcc structure of Ir was observed for Ir/α-Al2O3 in the 2θ range of 37°–47°. For the optimal catalyst of Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 (1 wt% Ru, 4 wt% Ir), a peak of fcc (111) was observed at a position shifted from that of Ir toward a higher angle. This result suggests the formation of Ir-rich IrRu solid solution alloy with fcc structure. For the catalysts with high Ru ratio (4 wt% or 3 wt% Ru), peaks of hcp structure were observed at a position shifted from that of pure Ru toward a lower angle. This result suggests the formation of Ru-rich solid solution alloy with hcp structure. Previous studies regarding IrRu bimetallic systems also reported similar peak shifts of Ir0 (111) or Ru0 (101) diffraction peaks, invoking such shifts as the evidence of Ir-Ru alloy formation [85]. The metal crystallite size in Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 was calculated to be 4.3 nm, although there can be underestimation due to the broadening derived from the heterogeneity of composition. The XRD patterns of the catalysts after the reuse tests are shown in Fig. 7 A, and the enlarged view of the Ru-Ir alloy peaks is shown in Fig. 7B. The catalyst after the first cycle provided the alloy-derived peaks with increased intensity compared to the fresh catalyst. These XRD patterns suggest that the aggregation of metal particles occurred during the first use in the reaction. In contrast, no further aggregation of metal particles was observed with the increase in the reuse runs. The catalyst deactivation in the repeated uses without regeneration (Fig. 5) can be thus due to the deposition of organic species, not to the aggregation. TEM-EDX measurement was conducted to investigate the morphology and distribution of supported metals in the spent catalysts (Fig. 8 ). The metal particles of all the catalysts were not uniformly distributed on α-Al2O3 and rather were agglomerated. Some of the agglomerated particles were loosely connected to the support surface, especially as shown in Fig. 8B, suggesting the weak interaction of support and metal particles. The size of primary particles seemed to be slightly larger for Ru/α-Al2O3 and Ir/α-Al2O3, compared to Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3. The mean diameter of primary particles of Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 was about 5 nm. The EDX analysis of Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 showed that the positions of Ru and Ir were approximately the same, which supported the formation of their alloy. In addition, the EDX point analysis (Fig. 8B’’) demonstrated that the Ru/Ir ratio at each point where metal species existed matched the Ru/Ir ratio based on their loading amounts (1:4 in weight), confirming the formation of well-mixed alloy particles. To investigate the metal dispersion, CO adsorption measurement was conducted (Table 3 ). Among the bimetallic catalysts, Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 (1 wt% Ru, 4 wt% Ir), which is the optimal catalyst, showed the highest metal dispersion. The dispersion value (13 %) was lower than that expected from the crystallite size (26 %, corresponding to 4.3 nm calculated from the XRD pattern), and the difference could originate from the agglomeration of metal crystallites. In addition, the low dispersion from CO adsorption in comparison with the particle sizes of air-exposed samples determined by XRD and TEM suggests the absence of highly dispersed species that cannot be observed by XRD and TEM or can be easily oxidized by the contact with air. The monometallic catalysts showed higher metal dispersion compared to the bimetallic catalysts. High TOF of bimetallic catalysts was the main cause of higher activity rather than the difference of dispersion. For more detailed structural analysis, XAFS measurements were conducted. The shape of the XANES spectra of Ru K-edge and Ir L 3-edge (Fig. S3) confirm that the Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 in different ratios, Ru/α-Al2O3, and Ir/α-Al2O3 all have the zero valent metallic state during the reaction. The EXAFS curve fitting was conducted to determine the coordination number and bond distances of the metals (Table 4 ; detailed data in Table S15 and Figs. S4–S5). The ratios of the RuRu/RuIr coordination numbers were approximately consistent with the molar ratios of Ru/Ir in the catalyst. This suggested that each particle was the alloy with uniform composition, agreeing well with the TEM-EDX results described above. For the bond distance, IrIr and RuIr bond distances of Ir/α-Al2O3 catalyst and the Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 (1 wt% Ru, 4 wt% Ir) catalyst were longer than those of the other catalysts. On the other hand, the catalysts with higher Ru content (3–5 wt% Ru) exhibited shorter RuRu and RuIr bond distances than those of the other catalysts. These results suggest the differences in the crystal structure between the Ir-rich and Ru-rich catalysts. Indeed, as demonstrated by XRD, the Ir-rich catalysts had fcc alloy, while the Ru-rich catalysts had hcp alloy. Carbon-supported Ir-Ru catalysts with various molar ratio have been also investigated in the field of electrochemistry [86–89]. The catalyst structure in these works is similar to our results: solid solution alloy with hcp and fcc structure for Ru-rich and Ir-rich catalysts, respectively. 3.5 Reaction mechanism The aforementioned reaction results posited the involvement of two types of pathways in the HDN of 1-CEA over Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3: direct CN bond cleavage and CN bond cleavage following the formation of the coupled compound. The main route for the HDN of 1-CEA with optimum Ru-Ir/Al2O3 catalyst is direct CN bond cleavage, and neither the optimal support α-Al2O3 nor the optimal solvent alkanes are involved in the reaction, suggesting that direct CN bond cleavage occurs on metal. As described in Section 3.1.2, the catalyst with 3 wt% Ir and 2 wt% Ru (Ru/Ir = 1.3 in mol) showed the highest TOF value, while that with 4 wt% Ir and 1 wt% Ru (Ru/Ir = 0.48 in mol) showed higher activity because of the comparable TOF value and higher dispersion. Considering that higher Ru/Ir ratio above 2/3 (in weight; 1.3 in mol) changed the alloy structure from fcc to hcp, the fcc alloy with the molar ratio around 1:1 is the most active (high TOF). Regarding the direct CN bond cleavage, Sinfelt et al. proposed the reaction mechanism for the CN bond cleavage of methylamine on Rh/SiO2 catalyst [26]. According to their study, the CHxNHy species were adsorbed onto the catalyst surface, and then the CN bond was dissociated using vacant sites of Rh surface. The CN bond cleavage was suggested to be the rate-determining step because the reaction rate had negative dependence on hydrogen pressure while zero-order dependence on amine concentration. Such kinetic behavior means that hydrogen and amine are adsorbed on different sites; if the negative dependence on hydrogen pressure is derived from the competitive adsorption of H2 and amine, first-order dependence on amine concentration appears at low concentration levels and the total conversion of amine takes long time. In our case using the Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 catalyst, the results of hydrogen pressure effect showed the negative dependence on hydrogen pressure especially in the pressure range of 1 MPa or above, and the time course showed zero-order dependence on amine concentration. Therefore, the mechanism for the direct CN bond cleavage of 1 MPa or above was assumed to be similar to that proposed by Sinfelt et al. involving the CN bond cleavage as the rate-determining step. In the ammonia decomposition over Ru or Ir surface, it has been proposed that there are various adsorbed nitrogen-containing intermediate species: MNH3 on top sites, (M)2NH2 on bridge sites, (M)3NH on hollow sites, and (M)3N on hollow sites [90–92]. On the other hand, it is well known that hydrogen is dissociatively adsorbed on hollow sites of metal surface. Therefore, the adsorption sites for RNH2 and RNH species can be different from those of hydrogen, while RN species will be competitively adsorbed with hydrogen species. The kinetic behavior suggests that the reaction of adsorbed RNH2 or RNH species with the vacant site for hydrogen adsorption is the rate-determining step. On the other hand, regarding the formation pathway of the coupled compound, there are several reports of coupling reactions between two primary aliphatic amine molecules using metal-based heterogeneous catalysts [64–66,93]. According to these reports, the amine coupling reaction proceeds in the following sequence: (1) the abstraction of a hydride from amine by a metal catalyst leading to the formation of primary imine compound, (2) the imine readily reacts with another amine molecule to form the corresponding secondary imine even without catalyst, and (3) the secondary imine is hydrogenated to the corresponding secondary amine with the hydrogen species generated in the step (1) or external H2. The rate-determining step is suggested to be the step (1), the dehydrogenation of primary amine to corresponding primary imine.Assuming that the coupling reaction of 1-CEA proceeds via a similar mechanism, 1-CEA undergoes the dehydrogenation to form the primary imine (1-cyclohexylethanimine) before the further reaction steps. Fig. 9 (detailed data: Table S16) shows the results of the reaction conducted under an Ar atmosphere using the Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 catalyst. The conversion under Ar was higher about twice than that under hydrogen, indicating that the substrate was activated and converted even in the absence of hydrogen. The main product under Ar was the secondary imine via the coupling reaction, and 1-cyclohexylethanimine was also detected. These results demonstrate that the formation of the coupling intermediate proceeds via the imine intermediates. Considering that 2 mol of substrate was consumed in the coupling with 1 mol of 1-cyclohexylethanimine formation, the dehydrogenation rate of the substrate to form 1-cyclohecylethanimine under Ar was similar to the reaction rate of HDN at low hydrogen pressure (≤1 MPa). Furthermore, the elucidation of the effect of hydrogen pressure on the HDN of 1-CEA showed that the selectivity pattern was almost independent of the hydrogen pressure (Fig. 3). This suggests that the adsorbed species before the imine formation is common to that in the direct CN bond cleavage pathway. Based on these considerations, the proposed reaction pathway is shown in Scheme 2 . The substrate was strongly adsorbed on the metal surface with the abstraction of one hydrogen atom of the amino group. Subsequently, CN bond cleavage by the reaction over the vacant site for hydrogen adsorption (hollow site) leads to the formation of surface 1-cyclohexylethyl species and NH species on the hollow site, which are hydrogenated into ethylcyclohexane and ammonia, respectively. On the other hand, if the hydrogen atom at the carbon atom next to the nitrogen atom is abstracted by the vacant site for hydrogen adsorption, the primary imine is formed, facilitating the coupling reaction. Based on the results shown in Fig. 9, it is suggested that the dehydrogenation proceeds more readily in the absence of hydrogen, while CN bond cleavage proceeds more readily in the presence of hydrogen. To investigate the respective roles of Ru and Ir in the HDN of amines over Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3, the hydrogen pressure dependence was studied for the three catalysts: Ru/α-Al2O3, Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3, and Ir/α-Al2O3 (Fig. S6, detailed data: Table S17). For all the catalysts, their activity increased at lower hydrogen pressure, and the product selectivities were not changed much in different pressure. These results suggest that the reaction mechanisms are not significantly different among these three catalysts. It can be inferred that there is no clear difference in the role of each metal. Additionally, based on the time course results presented in Section 3.3.1 (Fig. 4, detailed data: Table S12), the reactions using Ru/α-Al2O3 and Ir/α-Al2O3 proceeded more slowly than that using Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3. In particular, Ru/α-Al2O3 showed low activity and a large decline in the reaction rate over time. These results could imply that competitive adsorption between the substrate and hydrogen may occur on Ru/α-Al2O3. In addition, Ir/α-Al2O3 showed the higher selectivity to the coupled compound. It is suggested that the dehydrogenation proceeds more readily on Ir, and the CN cleavage pathway becomes more prominent in the presence of Ru, which has high hydrogen activation ability [94]. To further investigate the properties of Ru and Ir in detail, propylamine was adsorbed on the catalyst, and temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) tests were conducted as shown in Fig. 10 . The amount of each desorbed compound is summarized in Table 5 . The signals of m/z = 59, 44, 28, 16, and 2 corresponds to the desorption of propylamine, propane, N2, NH3, and H2, respectively. In the TPD pretreatment, hydrogen was also adsorbed after the propylamine adsorption. For all the catalysts, the desorption peaks were observed not only for propylamine but also for its hydrogenolysis products, i.e., propane and NH3. In addition, the desorption peaks were observed for the decomposition products of NH3, i.e., N2 and H2. The desorbed amount of propylamine was much lower than the amount of hydrogenolysis products for all the cases, indicating the strong adsorption of substrate. The desorbed amount of propane and NH3 was larger than the surface metal sites for all the cases, suggesting that propylamine adsorbed on support was involved in the reaction as a hydrogen donor. The desorbed amount of N atoms, which is calculated from the desorbed amounts of propylamine, N2, and NH3 below 623 K follows the order: Ir/α-Al2O3 (155 μmol/g) > Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 (118 μmol/g) > Ru/α-Al2O3 (67 μmol/g). This trend suggests that Ir adsorbs more amine species than Ru does. On the other hand, catalysts containing Ru provided the larger desorption amount of H2 than Ir/α-Al2O3. The profile for the desorption of H2 from Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 had a shoulder peak at around 473 K. This shoulder signal was located at higher temperature than the desorption peaks of N2 and propane, which means that the peak was derived from the desorption of hydrogen adspecies formed at lower temperature. Such H2 desorption was not observed in the case of Ir/α-Al2O3. These data suggest that Ru enhances the adsorption of H2, which may play a significant role in promoting the HDN reaction. In the desorption profiles of H2 and propane for Ru/α-Al2O3, the peaks were observed at higher temperature (>523 K) compared to those observed for the other catalysts, suggesting that Ru strongly adsorbs H2 and propane. These results are consistent with reports that hydrogen is adsorbed more strongly on a Ru surface than on an Ir surface, while NH3 is adsorbed more strongly on an Ir surface than on a Ru surface [91]. The strong adsorption of hydrogen means that the high reactivity of vacant site for hydrogen activation. Although both monometallic catalysts have activity in HDN, the combination of good ability of Ru and Ir for the activation of H2 and amine, respectively, can give better performance of bimetallic Ru-Ir catalyst. Applicability of the reaction pathways in Scheme 2 is not proved to other catalysts. While the support does not participate in the reaction pathway in Scheme 2, the reaction results in Fig. 1 showed that support much affects the reaction results, especially the activity in the coupling reaction. There is another reaction pathway promoted by support when other supports are used. 4 Conclusions We have reported the hydrodenitrogenation (HDN) of 1-cyclohexylethylamine (1-CEA) to ethylcyclohexane in good yields (94 %) using the Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 catalyst (1 wt% Ru, 4 wt% Ir) in a decane solvent. The HDN reaction of 1-CEA over this catalyst proceeds via both direct CN bond cleavage and CN bond cleavage following the formation of the coupled compound. This catalyst is also effective for the HDN reaction of other amines, where substrates with low steric hindrance undergo the CN bond cleavage after the formation of the coupled compound. The Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 catalyst consists of uniform Ru-Ir alloy particles with approximately 4 nm in size, and this alloy phase serves as the active site. This reaction showed the negative dependence on hydrogen pressure, suggesting that the dehydrogenated adspecies acts as an intermediate. An appropriate hydrogen pressure (1 MPa) leads to the high yield of target product. Although a slight decrease in the activity is observed, the catalyst can be reused without regeneration. From the amine TPD, it was suggested that Ru has high H2 activation ability and Ir has high amine adsorption ability, and the combination can give better performance. coredata.dc:description: Hydrodenitrogenation (HDN) of 1-cyclohexylethylamine to ethylcyclohexane was investigated with various Ru-based catalysts. Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 (1 wt% Ru, 4 wt% Ir) catalyst was found to be superior to other supported Ru catalysts in terms of activity and selectivity to ethylcyclohexane. Characterization with XRD, TEM-EDX and XAFS showed that uniform Ru-Ir alloy particles of approximately 4 nm in size were formed on α-Al2O3. The optimal Ru-Ir/α-Al2O3 catalyst gave 94 % yield of ethylcyclohexane. The time-course results and the reaction results of bis-(1-cyclohexylethyl)-amine (coupled compound of the substrate) demonstrated that the direct CN cleavage route and indirect route via the coupled compound both proceeded in the HDN of 1-cyclohexylethylamine. The propylamine-TPD results with H2 treatment after the adsorption of propylamine on the catalyst suggested that the adsorption of H2 and amine was favorable on the Ru and Ir species, respectively. The catalyst was reusable after washing with ethanol with a slight loss of activity. The catalyst was also effective for the HDN reaction of other amines, and the HDN of some substrates proceeded mainly in the indirect route via the coupled compound.
